text:
Transition in McSherrystown

Editor, Gettysburg Times,

McSherrystown Borough has been advised that neither it nor its officials
should publicly disclose personnel matters.

Despite that advice, at the May 27, 2020 Borough Council meeting, a council
member chose to ignore that advice and launched into his own commentary
regarding a personnel issue which, I believe, was misinformed.

A second council member took advantage of the chaos created by the outburst,
also ignoring those instructions. In my opinion, sensitive and potentially
legally-protected information concerning current and past borough personnel
was discussed publicly. During these statements, the technology used to host
the meeting did not permit me, as the council president to comment, to caution
or otherwise interact with these council members. Although order was
eventually restored, it is my opinion that the civility and decorum residents
expect from their council was lost.

Equally concerning to me is that employees may feel as if the privacy, to
which they are entitled as employees, was compromised. While we are grateful
for the ability technology grants us to bring these meetings to you, the
unfortunate circumstances that occurred during this meeting has resulted in
new measures that we will be implementing immediately to assure, should there
be an additional attempt by any member(s) to cause a disruption, there will be
immediate actions to stop disturbances followed swiftly by any corrective
action which the Borough Code may permit.

The Borough's response to an evolving personnel situation was meant to be
deliberate and transparent, and we will attempt to regain the composure,
resolve, and patience needed to do what is best for our Borough, which
includes its taxpayers, residents, staff, and its elected officials.

Sometimes what is best for all stakeholders takes times and patience to
discern clearly. We are currently researching options and developing a plan to
move forward, cautiously, and deliberately. Our focus is to assess our current
strengths while creating a comprehensive overview, which will outline the
qualifications which will best serve the needs of our borough moving forward.
When we are ready to advertise for this position, we will notify the community
and publish the qualifications we are seeking. In the meantime, our staff and
council will manage affairs appropriately and effectively. Thank you for your
understanding and patience as we navigate this period of transition.

William F. Smith Jr.,

McSherrystown
